supporting_text: The NAP emphasizes a One Health approach, integrating efforts across human, animal, and environmental health sectors.
Strategy 3 focuses on infection prevention and control and antimicrobial stewardship in humans.
Strategy 4 addresses AMR prevention and control and antimicrobial stewardship in agriculture and animals.
The NAP includes actions related to environmental contamination of AMR organisms.
Strategy 4 includes actions for reducing antimicrobial use in livestock farming and fisheries.
Monitoring and evaluation of the implementation will be based on a developmental evaluation approach, including measurement of progress towards defined milestones.
The NAP sets specific targets such as a 50% reduction in AMR morbidity and a 20% increase in public knowledge by 2021.
The NAP includes quantitative targets such as a 20% reduction in antimicrobial consumption in humans and a 30% reduction in animals.
The document does not specify budget allocations for the strategies.
There is no assessment of future budget requirements mentioned in the document.
The NAP mentions the establishment of a Coordination and Integration Committee on Antimicrobial Resistance.
The NAP includes strategies for regulating antimicrobial distribution and promoting rational drug use.
The NAP includes actions to improve health literacy on AMR and awareness of appropriate use of antimicrobials.
The NAP includes actions to support roles of civil society and mass media agencies to increase public understanding of AMR.
The NAP emphasizes Thailand's proactive and collaborative role in AMR at the international level.
Strategy 1 focuses on strengthening the national integrated system of AMR surveillance.
The NAP includes actions to improve epidemiological capacity and networking on AMR.
Strategy 3 includes infection prevention and control measures in healthcare facilities.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes strategies for regulating antimicrobial distribution.
The NAP includes a national policy on promoting rational drug use in hospitals.
The NAP emphasizes the need for international collaboration in addressing AMR.
